titlePart.entryReference: arrangements of vessel ventilation, heating, cooling, or air-conditioning

titlePart.text: Hydrodynamic or hydrostatic features of hulls or of hydrofoils
titlePart.entryReference: decreasing pitch, roll, or like unwanted vessel movements by using foils acting on ambient water

titlePart.text: deriving lift mainly from water displacement
deriving additional lift from hydrodynamic forces

titlePart.entryReference: controlling submarine attitude or depth by hydroplanes

titlePart.text: having more than one planing surface
Other means for varying the inherent hydrodynamic characteristics of hulls
using air bubbles or air layers

titlePart.entryReference: designing, building, maintaining, or repairing methods

titlePart.text: Hulls built to withstand hydrostatic pressure when fully submerged, e.g. submarine hulls
characterised by being formed predominantly of parts that may be developed into plane surfaces
Means for diminishing external ridges or protrusions
Reinforcements for carrying localised loads, e.g. propulsion plant, guns
Hulls characterised by their construction of non-metallic material
made predominantly of wood with metal reinforcement, i.e. composite construction
made predominantly of concrete, e.g. reinforced
in combination with elements of other materials
with reinforcing members external to shell
Collapsible, foldable, inflatable, or like vessels
Methods of designing, building, maintaining, converting, refitting, repairing, or determining properties of, vessels, not otherwise provided for
Using towing tanks or model basins for designing
Determining vessel properties with respect to stability or balance
Arrangement of bulkheads, e.g. defining cargo spaces
Constructional features of bunkers or ballast tanks, e.g. with elastic walls
Ports for passing water through vessels' sides
Staying of masts or of other superstructures
Vessels parts, details, or accessories, not otherwise provided for

titlePart.entryReference: removal of domestic or like refuse

titlePart.text: Arrangements or adaptations of ports, doors, windows, port-holes, or other openings or covers
titlePart.entryReference: arrangements of watertight doors in bulkheads

titlePart.text: Air-catching equipment related to windows or port-holes
Ports or like openings in vessels' sides
actuated by cables or the like

titlePart.entryReference: equipment for shipping in harbours, e.g. for landing purposes,

titlePart.text: Fastening or guiding equipment for chains, ropes, hawsers, or the like
Adaptations of chains, ropes, hawsers, or the like, or of parts thereof
titlePart.entryReference: chains, ropes or hawsers in general, see the relevant sub-classes, e.g.

titlePart.text: by weight, e.g. flukeless weight anchors
with variable, e.g. sliding, connection to chain
Anchoring arrangements for special vessels, e.g. for floating drilling platforms or dredgers

titlePart.entryReference: adaptations or arrangements for marking navigational routes

titlePart.text: characterised by moving of more than one vessel
Equipment for towing or pushing vessels by vehicles or beings moving forward on ground-based paths along water-way
titlePart.entryReference: shore- or ground-based equipment per se, e.g. vehicles, rails, see the relevant classes

titlePart.text: Equipment specially adapted for towing underwater objects or vessels, e.g. fairings for tow-cables
Equipment for handling lifeboats or the like
Davits, i.e. devices having arms for lowering boats by cables or the like
with arms pivoting on substantially-horizontal axes, e.g. gravity type
with positive drive of the arms
with arms pivoting on substantially-vertical axes
with rectilinear translation of boat before lowering
Devices for projecting or releasing boats for free fall
Devices for guiding boats to water surface
Rigid guides, e.g. having arms pivoted near waterline
Guiding means for lowering by cables, e.g. for listing ships
Transport of boats to davits or the like
Use of lowering or hoisting gear
with control of winches from boat
Additional connections between boat and davit
Fastening or storing of boats on deck

titlePart.entryReference: trimming otherwise than by cargo division. e.g. by use of ballast, ,

titlePart.text: for motor vehicles or the like
Means for preventing unwanted cargo movement, e.g. dunnage
Arrangement of ship-based loading or unloading equipment for cargo or passengers
titlePart.entryReference: loading or unloading devices per se, see the relevant sub-classes, e.g. , ,

titlePart.text: of ramps, gangways or outboard ladders

titlePart.entryReference: mechanical throwing machines for articles or solid materials per se

titlePart.text: for transfer at sea between ships or between ships and off-shore structures

titlePart.entryReference: devices for facilitating retrieval of floating objects per se

titlePart.text: Accommodation for crew or passengers not otherwise provided for
Storm guards on tables, e.g. fiddles
Washing or bathing facilities peculiar to ships
Arrangements or adaptations of swimming pools
Vessels or like floating structures not otherwise provided for
titlePart.entryReference: vessels characterised by load- accommodating arrangements
containers for use in or under water

titlePart.text: for moving cable-ends from ship to shore
having forced pitching or rolling equipment
for collecting pollution from open water
Floating buildings, stores, drilling platforms, or workshops, e.g. carrying water-oil separating devices
Vessels or floating structures for aircraft
titlePart.entryReference: flying-boat hulls, other flotation means for aircraft

titlePart.text: Nets, slipways or the like, for recovering aircraft from the water
Other vessels or like floating structures for pleasure or sport
titlePart.entryReference: water skis or like appliances for gliding on water

titlePart.text: Equipment to decrease pitch, roll, or like unwanted vessel movements
to decrease vessel movements by displacement of masses
to decrease vessel movements by using gyroscopes directly
to decrease vessel movements by using foils acting on ambient water
to decrease vessel movements by using auxiliary jets or propellers
titlePart.entryReference: using auxiliary jets or propellers for steering or dynamic anchoring

titlePart.text: to decrease vessel movements by damping the waves, e.g. by pouring oil on water
for indicating inclination or duration of roll
Drop keels, e.g. centre boards, side boards
Improving safety of vessels, e.g. damage control, not otherwise provided for
reducing risk of capsizing or sinking
titlePart.entryReference: by means of watertight doors in bulkheads

titlePart.text: Temporary equipment for stopping leaks, e.g. collision mats
Arrangements of watertight doors in bulkheads
Arrangement or adaptation of signalling or lighting devices
the devices being intended to illuminate the way ahead or other areas of environments
the devices being intended to indicate the vessel or parts thereof
the devices being intended to illuminate vessels' decks or interior
Arrangements of nautical instruments or navigational aids
Tank cleaning specially adapted for vessels

titlePart.entryReference: cleaning of vehicles in general, e.g. windscreen wipers,
inhibiting corrosion of metals by anodic or cathodic protection

titlePart.text: using trolleys or the like driven along the surface
